Further, the North Muskegon Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58 [2014]) requirements for LP Gas storage. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, if a release does occur, a Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with the Muskegon Charter Township Fire Department, North Muskegon Fire Department, and Muskegon County Emergency Services.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The North Muskegon Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The terminal keeps records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. This is a new butane blending process; consequently, there have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the chemical release of materials covered under the EPA RMP regulation.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Response actions are coordinated with the Muskegon Charter Township Fire Department an

d North Muskegon Fire Department. A Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.

Marathon - North Muskegon Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and associated 14 elements (29 CFR Part 1910.119), and all applicable state and local laws and regulations. The butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer's (Sunoco Partners Marketing & Terminals, L.P.), instructions and recommendations.

In the event of an emergency involving the North Muskegon Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Muskegon Charter Township Fire Department and request their assistance. The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire capability. The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Muskegon Charter Township Fire Department, North Muskegon Fire Department, and Muskegon County Emergency Services. The Muskegon Charter Township Fire Department and North Muskegon Fire Department have participated in the initial PSM/RMP training session for this system.

Marathon also maintain a relationship with the Muskegon Charter Township Fire Department and North Muskegon Fire Department. Tours and drills with members of local emergency response organizations are held routinely. These tours and drills enable the public emergency responders to become familiar with the hazards, equipment, resources and personnel in the terminal.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Marathon is continually striving to make the North Muskegon Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for our employees, our neighbors and our community.

In an effort t

o improve and promote system safety, Marathon looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements. The Muskegon Charter Township Fire Department and North Muskegon Fire Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills. Additionally, Marathon will work cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

Marathon Petroleum Company LP - North Muskegon Terminal is a refined petroleum products distributor. The North Muskegon Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of North Muskegon, MI. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.

Marathon Petroleum Company LP (Marathon) - North Muskegon Terminal in North Muskegon, MI is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Marathon believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The North Muskegon Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of our employees, contractors and the community. Marathon promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Marathon has designed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals
D. An overview of the emergency response program
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The primary function of the North Muskegon Terminal, located in North Muskegon, MI is to act as a refined petroleum distribution facility.

The butane blending process has been classified as Program level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances were identified. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community along with the surrounding environment. Marathon Petroleum Company LP - North Muskegon Terminal is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety/control devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the North Muskegon Terminal.

The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in two (2) storage vessels. Specifically, liquefied butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure. The butane is pumped to a blending skid for direct injection into regular and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via an injection skid and analyzer. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point (<250 degrees Fahrenheit) fusible elements(fail safe), 85% fill shutoff on the vessel, emergency shutoff devices on the system and video display terminal, line thermal (pressure) reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the North Muskegon Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC
PREVENTION MEASURES

Marathon's accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning and response programs help effectively manage t

he hazards posed by our regulated substances to our employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29CFR 1910.119. The following accident prevention program elements are in place at the North Muskegon Terminal:

1) Employee Participation
2) Process Safety Information
3) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
4) Standard Operating Procedures
5) Operator Training
6) Contractors
7) Pre-startup Safety Review
8) Mechanical Integrity with Preventive Maintenance
9) Work Permits
10) Management of Change
11) Accident or Potential Catastrophic Event Investigation
12) Emergency Response
13) Compliance Audits
14) Trade Secrets

These fourteen (14) individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. Our company and our employees are committed to the standards required by these management programs. In addition to the above elements, we also have specific prevention measures that are employed as part of our operating procedures and engineering and administrative controls to help contain/control a release, quickly detect a release, and reduce the consequences of a release. -Engineering and construction in accordance with recognized industry and company standards
-Equipment properly designed with protection from overpressure (pressure safety relief valves, etc.)
-Updated technical drawings, Piping & Instrument Diagrams and Process Flow Diagrams
-Operating systems monitored and controlled by trained Operators
-Computerized monitoring and control of process operation
-Redundant control systems with battery back-ups
-Automatic and manual shutdown devices for critical systems
-Scheduled inspection and testing of instruments, analyzers, and safety devices
